text: I’m Randi Harper. I’m a Technical Evangelist for Amazon Web Services.
Today I'm going to show you how easy it is to backup your Oracle database to the AWS Cloud.
Let’s say you have an Oracle database.
Traditionally, when planning for disaster recovery, you would create regular backups
of your database with tapes to be stored offsite.
Managing this process can require a lot of work.
You have to obtain expensive software, the hardware, the personnel,
and come up with a process to backup using expensive on-site tape robotic libraries
and also a process to make sure your offsite backups are up-to-date and secure.
As your database grows and your requirements change,
this gets more and more complex and costly to maintain.
In addition, if a disaster occurs,
you have to restore data from the tapes from an offsite location,
which can be a lengthy restore process.
This can significantly add to your downtime and costs.
In this tutorial, I’m going to show you how to utilize the AWS Cloud
as an a better alternative to using tapes for your database backups.
In the following videos, I'm going to create an Oracle database and then demonstrate
how to configure and use Oracle Recovery Manager, also known as Oracle RMAN,
with the Oracle Secure Backup, or OSB, Cloud Module to send database backups to Amazon S3.
Once this has been setup, I’m going to perform a backup of my database,
then I'm going to simulate some data corruption by removing a few important files.
I’ll then perform a restore operation to show you how using the OSB Cloud Module
with Amazon S3 is transparent to the database administrator.
When you use Amazon Web Services as your backup provider,
you benefit from our storage redundancy, security, availability,
and scalability with geographic distribution.
In the case of a disaster, there will be no need to call someone
and have tapes loaded or shipped.
Administrators can perform restore operations immediately using standard tools
just as if the offsite backup was stored locally.
It's extremely easy and simple to setup an Oracle database to
automatically backup to Amazon Simple Storage Service.
Amazon S3 is a highly durable and highly redundant distributed object store.
